content:
Edited to improve the formatting and fix a typo.
Previous version backup: https://pastebin.com/eTjUqmcj

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear, simple but not too easy, I like it !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: (*) The statement is concise and clear.
(*) This is a good target for "non-standard" (e.g. Dijkstra would be an standard greedy algorithm) greedy algorithms, of which I do not think there are many puzzles in the website.
(*) The difficulty does not stem from an arduous implementation, but from proving the correctness of the approach.

There seems to be some discussion regarding the difficulty level of the problem. I support the idea of categorizing it as hard, because that'd would be consistent with the "Super computer" classical puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the idea :smile: well work
HEADS UP - I would definitely recommend going into this problem blind without looking at the solution code. Use the "test in IDE" option.
I think it should be medium at most. You can tell immediately just by looking at the length of your solution code. I would vote against easy though.

All tests work fine. Statement is clear.
Difficulty should be Easy IMO
In tags String manipulation and sorting would be ok. It can be soved as bubble sort with condition

It's definitely not easy - implementing the solution is easy, but figuring out the solution is far beyond the reach of someone with beginner experience.

My solution is derived from the fact that since numbers of different polarity may not be swapped, the order of the subset of even/odd numbers will remain constant. Therefore, someone must spot that the correct approach is to take the maximum integer from the front of either subset.

I'm of the opinion that length of solution does not always correlate with difficulty, but I can see a case being made for medium. Greedy algorithms tend to appear a lot easier once you have already solved it.
In my view, if the "Super Computer" classic puzzle is in the "hard" category, this one should also be hard for consistency.

I think I understand what you mean a bit better now - this problem can not be solved using bubble sort, as it does not always produce the optimal solution. For example, a greedy bubble sort approach will fail on test 4, as the 9 and 4 will not be swapped.

I have solved it with approach very similar to bubble sort, just added additional 'if' condition. 

Solved it in 10 minutes which deserve easy difficulty.

Can you show your code? A simple bubble sort that simply does not preform swaps if two adjacent numbers are of same polarity should fail, so I'm sure you're probably doing something different from what I'm envisioning.
